title: A Phase 2 Multi-center, Randomized, Double Blind, Placebo-controlled, Parallel Group Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of T-817MA in Patients With Mild to Moderate Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief:
The primary objective is to evaluate the efficacy of T-817MA as measured by ADAS-cog and ADCS-CGIC.

The secondary objectives are:

* To evaluate the safety and tolerability of T-817MA measured by clinical safety laboratories, physical examinations, ECGs and solicitation of adverse events.
* To evaluate the efficacy of T-817MA as measured by ADCS-ADL, FAQ, Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) and Mini-mental State Examination (MMSE).

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: The overall numbers of baseline participants display patient numbers in the mITT population, the primary analysis population. The mITT population excludes patients who did not take any study drug or did not perform any efficacy evaluation post-baseline. Thus, the numbers are slightly difference from the ones in the participant flow.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measures.title: MMSE
measures.description: The Mini Mental Scale Examination (MMSE) is a validated, brief, frequently used screening instrument for Alzheimer's disease drug studies. The MMSE scale evaluates orientation, memory, attention, concentration, naming, repetition, comprehension, and ability to create a sentence and to copy two overlapping pentagons. The MMSE is scored as the number of correctly completed items with a lower score indicative of poorer performance and greater cognitive impairment. The total score ranges from 0 (worse) to 30 (perfect performance).

outcomeMeasures.title: ADAS-cog Change From Baseline to Week 52
outcomeMeasures.description: The ADAS-cog (Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-cognitive subscale) is a structured scale that evaluates memory (word recall, word recognition), reasoning (following commands), language (naming, comprehension), orientation, ideational praxis (placing letter in envelope) and constructional praxis (copying geometric designs). Ratings of spoken language, language comprehension, word finding difficulty, and ability to remember test instructions are also obtained. The test is scored in terms of errors, with higher scores reflecting poorer performance and greater impairment. Scores can range from 0 (best) to 70 (worse).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The overall number of participants display the numbers of patients who were included in the mITT population and had baseline and at least one post-baseline ADAS-cog evaluation.

outcomeMeasures.title: CGIC
outcomeMeasures.description: The ADCS-CGIC (Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study-Clinical Global Impression of Change) is a validated categorical measure of change in the patient's clinical condition between baseline and follow-up visits. It measures whether the effects of active treatment are substantial enough to be detected by a skilled and experienced clinician on the basis of a clinical interview and examination. It relies on both direct examination of the patient and an interview of the study partner. A skilled and experienced clinician who is blinded to treatment assignment rates the patient on a 7-point Likert scale, ranging from 1 (marked improvement) to 7 (marked worsening). It is suggested that the instrument has distinct clinical utility in assessing change in AD clinical trials.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The overall number of participants display the numbers of patients who were included in the mITT population and had at least one post-baseline CGIC evaluation.

outcomeMeasures.title: ADCS-ADL Change From Baseline to Week 52
outcomeMeasures.description: The ADCS-ADL (Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study Activities of Daily Living) is a validated tool for assessing instrumental and basic activities of daily living based on a 23-item structured interview of the study partner. The scale has a range of 0 to 78, with lower scores indicating greater impairment.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The overall number of participants display the numbers of patients who were included in the mITT population and had baseline and at least one post-baseline ADCS-ADL evaluation.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests T-817MA (also called edonerpic maleate) in mild–moderate AD with primary cognitive endpoints (ADAS-cog and ADCS-CGIC), indicating the intention to affect disease-related cognitive decline rather than only manage neuropsychiatric symptoms. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Act: T-817MA/edonerpic is a small-molecule, neuroprotective/neurotrophic agent shown in preclinical studies to protect against Aβ-induced neurotoxicity, preserve synapses, promote neurite outgrowth, and possibly act via sigma-1 receptor activation or AMPA receptor delivery — i.e., it targets AD-related pathophysiology rather than being a biologic or a purely symptomatic cognitive enhancer. The trial also has companion studies measuring AD biomarkers (e.g., CSF p-tau181), supporting a disease-targeting intent. citeturn0search7turn0search3turn0search2

Reflect: Classification as a "disease-targeted small molecule" fits because T-817MA is a small-molecule drug with proposed neuroprotective actions on AD pathology (synapse preservation/neurotrophic effects), and the trials use disease-relevant cognitive and biomarker endpoints. Note: clinical Phase 2 results did not demonstrate clear efficacy on cognition or biomarkers, but that does not change the intended target class. citeturn0search3turn0search6
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests T-817MA (edonerpic maleate), a disease-targeted small molecule developed to be neuroprotective and to enhance synaptic plasticity/neurotrophic processes (intended to slow disease-related cognitive decline rather than only treat symptoms). Evidence and trial endpoints (ADAS-cog, ADCS‑CGIC, CSF p‑tau biomarker measurement) indicate a disease-modifying/neuroprotective intent. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Extracted details — drug: T-817MA (edonerpic maleate); modality: small molecule; proposed mechanisms: synapse preservation, promotion of neurite outgrowth and AMPA receptor delivery, CRMP2 binding, and possible sigma‑1 receptor activation and microglial modulation. These mechanisms point to enhancement of synaptic plasticity and neuroprotection rather than direct amyloid- or tau-lowering as a primary mechanism. Key supporting sources: JAMA Neurology report of the Phase 2 trial and mechanistic/preclinical studies; Science 2018 paper showing CRMP2 binding and facilitation of synaptic AMPA receptor delivery. citeturn0search0turn1search0turn0search2

Reflect: CADRO mapping — the most specific fit is M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection because the drug is a neuroplasticity enhancer/neuroprotective small molecule (synapse preservation, AMPA trafficking, neurite outgrowth). It is not primarily an anti-amyloid (A), anti-tau (B), ApoE/lipid (C), inflammation (F) or proteostasis (I) agent, though secondary effects on microglia or tau biomarkers were evaluated. The Phase 2 trial did not demonstrate clinical efficacy, but that does not change the intended mechanism or the CADRO category. citeturn0search3turn0search2

Web search results (key sources used): (1) JAMA Neurology Phase 2 randomized trial summarizing safety, endpoints and negative efficacy findings for edonerpic maleate (T-817MA). citeturn0search0 (2) PubMed record / abstract of the Phase 2 trial (similar trial details and biomarker results). citeturn0search1 (3) Alzforum therapeutic page summarizing development history, trials, and biomarker/endpoint results for T-817MA/edonerpic. citeturn0search2 (4) Alzheimer's & Dementia conference/trial abstract with trial methods/results. citeturn0search3 (5) Science (Abe et al., 2018) demonstrating edonerpic binding to CRMP2 and facilitation of synaptic AMPA receptor delivery and enhanced plasticity/recovery in animal models. citeturn1search0
